Award.AwardTitle: Allatotropic Actions of Insulin in the Honey Bee
Award.AbstractNarration: Each year honey bees contribute billions of dollars of value to the United States economy by pollinating food crops. During the past decade, North American honey bee populations have declined, primarily because of the death of colonies during winter. The cause of these losses is mysterious, but one possibility is that reduced fall populations make winter survival more challenging. It is difficult to assess threats to bee health because little is known about basic bee physiology. This project fills gaps in our knowledge of bee reproduction by using molecular methods to identify brain hormones that regulate the ovaries in queens, the only females in bee colonies who can lay fertilized eggs. The results will define the brain regulation of bee reproduction, which can in turn be used to understand how factors such as pesticides and disease disrupt egg production and lead to reduced bee populations. Because one of these signals is an insulin-like peptide, these studies will promote understanding of the role of insulin in insects. Results will be published in peer-reviewed journals, with primary data stored for a minimum of 10 years on secure Wake Forest University servers in standard formats (Excel, Photoshop). Two educational projects will be supported by this award. First, undergraduates will investigate the ability of the honey bee gut to repair diet-induced damage. Students will partner with local citizen-beekeepers to survey gut health in bee populations in the Piedmont region of North Carolina. The second is development of an insect hormone laboratory exercise to be used by 200+ undergraduate biology students at Wake Forest University every semester. The curricular materials will be made available to all interested college-level instructors of biology through the national Association of Biology Laboratory Educators (ABLE). Insect-based exercises provide a safe, cost-effective tool for introducing students to concepts of hormone action.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Honey bee colonies are home to two very different types of females: a single queen and thousands of workers. Both queens and workers have ovaries, but the ovaries of workers are inactive. All young female honey bees (larvae) have the potential to develop as queens, but only the small number fed a diet of royal jelly do so. Many studies have documented how this difference in larval nutrition directs queens down a reproductive developmental path, but differences in the physiology of adult queens and workers have been less studied. This project investigated specific aspects of the hormonal regulation of reproduction and life histories in adult worker honey bees. The goal was to characterize the full hormonal profile of worker honey bees and to acquire evidence to test the hypothesis that insect insulin has different functions in adult queens and workers. The primary methods used were localization of tissue sites of insulin production and measures of blood concentrations of two categories of insect hormone associated with development and reproduction called ecdysteroids and juvenile hormone. Ecdysteroid levels were measured using an enzyme immunoassay, and juvenile hormone measurements were made using a high-resolution mass spectrometer. We identified small numbers of brain nerve cells that that are the likely source of circulating insect insulin, produced the first description of ecdysteroid profile covering the whole lifespan of adult worker honey bees, and optimized mass spectrometer methods for analysis of juvenile hormone in small blood samples. Blood samples were collected from worker honey bees injected with insulin (and appropriate control bees) to test the hypothesis that increased insulin will increase circulating juvenile hormone. At this point, the mass spectrometer malfunctioned and could not be repaired during the final month of project. All the samples have been securely stored, and are ready for analysis next summer, when the Principal Investigator’s schedule permits. These results have revealed new information about ecdysteroids in adult worker honey bees and, when the final phase is completed, will provide additional insight into the differences between queens and workers. This project also had three broader impact components, all successfully completed: the development of an inquiry-based insect hormones laboratory exercise now used by every undergraduate who takes introductory biology at Wake Forest University (approximately 500 students per year) since 2014; support of the professional development of two doctoral students, both of whom received their degrees in May 2016; and engagement of undergraduates in research and scientific conferences. One book chapter, two peer-reviewed manuscripts, two review articles, and two doctoral dissertations have been published or are in press, and graduate and undergraduate students have given oral and poster presentations at regional and national scientific meetings.
